title.title: The Correspondence of John Hunt and Joshua Evans

msIdentifier.institution: Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College

projectDesc.p: The correspondence of Quaker ministers John Hunt and Joshua Evans are stored at the Friends Historical Library of Swarthmore College. With the generous support of H. David and Joyce E. Hunt, Library staff scanned and transcribed these letters in 2023 and encoded the text in TEI. The 2023 project also included researching individuals mentioned in the text to create and update records about them in the Social Networks and Archival Context website

div.p: Enclosed is a letter from thy dear husband who I left a few days since at Pittsfield or parted with him there, he then having perhaps only two meetings to attend before his departure from the limits of this Yearly Meeting, for that of New York expecting to be first at East Hossack.

I left him under as deep a sensation of affectionate love, as my little measure would admit, after having been with him more than three months in which time he had attended including two Quarterly, eight Monthly, and several Preparative Meetings in many of which it was his lot to labor closely to the people in the love of the gospel (which seemed abundantly to overshadow his tabernacle) I hope to the awakening of some from a bed of ease and security. And I believe his encouraging communications has been a strength to a remnant in many places whose feet have been turned in the right way, and if there is a giving up and a full submission to the little discoveries in each mind the traces of his labor will not only be to be seen, but felt and experienced as waymarks to the generation that may succeed the present. I have thought much of him since I left him, and hope he has us, I often used to wish a better, more feeling and sympathizing companion, than he had in the greatest part of this Yearly Meeting, one whose experience
and faithfulness in the cause of truth might render them worthy to dip and feel with him, when traveling in the deeps for the arising of the pure life & light in our religious assemblies and elsewhere

That he may when his visit is accomplished return to thee and his dear family with the rich reward of a peaceful {mind} Mind is the earnest solitude of thy friend whose dear wife unites in affectionate love to thee and much desire thy continual support from best help during the trying separation allotted thee
